results.title: Altar masterpiece
results.brief_description: During the 15th Century the burghers of Krakow commissioned Wit Stwocz, master wood-carver and sculptor, to create a monumental altar-piece for St. Mary’s church, Krakow, the former capital of Poland. This film describes the altar-piece and its setting in medieval Krakow. It shows how the history of that period, its people, clothes and customs has been woven by Wit Stwocz into the story told in the altar’s carving.

results.title: Alpine sunshine
results.brief_description: Skiing in the Austrian Tyrol. Little villages of a few houses and hotels which are deserted in summer attract hundreds of tourists for winter sports. From the nursery slopes skiers graduate to the weekly races, full day excursions into the mountains, and long runs down from the top of the chair lift.

results.title: Almost a formal beginning
results.creator_credit: Richard Mitchell, Michael Robertson and Endeavour Production
results.brief_description: A tribute to the metal trades industry to mark its 1873-l973 centenary. Based on the concept of change, it shows the changes brought about in man’s life by the use of metal.

results.title: Allures
results.brief_description: Abstract animation by Jordan Belson. Intended to express “the subliminal rhythms of the inner cosmos”, this experimental film portrays an hallucinogenic voyage into outer space. It consists of sequences featuring interplay of dots, lines, planes, intricate kaleidoscopic designs, circles, grids, rhythms, textures, intensities and variations of focus. The images themselves often suggest the infinity of outer space or of subatomic particles, the snappy impersonality of computers or the undulation of romantic coloured clouds, provide filmed contrasts and tensions complemented by a musical soundtrack which itself acts as a counterpoint.

results.title: All the love
results.brief_description: Shows the work of the Spastic Society of Victoria in the care and treatment of the cerebral palsied. Activities are designed to suit individual cases, always with the aim of fitting them for a normal life. Shows a variety of therapeutic treatments, and the organization of workshops within the Centres and under contract to outside companies.

results.title: All in the game
results.creator_credit: Francis Fuchs, Eurfron Gwynne Jones and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Children Growing Up”.
Final part of the series considers all the aspects of development coming together in a study of play. The quality and type of play depend on all of them. Looks at the ways in which individual and group play develop. Narrated by Hugh David.

results.title: All I need is a conference
results.creator_credit: Robert Wilmot, Henry Strauss and General Electric
results.brief_description: Illustrates the uses that meetings and conferences can be made to serve, if guided by a trained and competent leader. Shows how the behaviour of people attending meetings is basically affected by the personal concerns they bring with them. Points out that the conference leader can deal successfully with the problem on the table only if he understands how to deal with the people around it. Dramatizes the pitfalls that can beset any meeting and the steps to take in order to avoid them.

results.title: Algeria
results.creator_credit: James Beveridge and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “The Crossroads of the world: a study of North Africa and the Middle East”.
Indicative of the direction and strength of Muslim revolt against European colonisers was the struggle for Algerian independence. This film recapitulates Algeria’s history up to the signing of the French-Algerian agreement and the last-ditch stand of the secret, outlaw European army. Figures of the Algerian resistance emerge on the screen as the film follows the Algerian resistance army to their mountain stronghold and takes a look at the peace conferences in France. Narrated by James Beveridge. Edited by Dennis Sawyer.
results.creator_credit_for_label: James Beveridge and National Film Board of Canada
